title: EastEnders' Muslim viewers slam the depiction of their religion on the soap: 'They're always boozing'
text:
Fans aren't happy (Photo: BBC) Share Get soaps updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
A number of Muslims have slammed EastEnders over the soap's depiction of their religion. 
The BBC show has become of the of the most diverse show's on television, and features a cast from all different walks of life and backgrounds. 
However, some eagle-eyed Muslims have noticed that characters like postman Maso Ahmed and Kush Kazema, are regulars at the Queen Vic. 
London student, Saleema, who is researching the topic for her PhD, has claimed that "many" Muslim women are "angry" at the iconic soap. Muslim fans are not pleased (Photo: BBC) They've claimed the characters drink too much (Photo: ITV) 
Many of them are thought to believe that the lack of positive role models on television are contributing to the divide between British Muslims and non-Muslims around the country. 
Alcohol is forbidden in the Koran, hence why some viewers belonging to the faith have become confused by the characters' frequenting of their local. 
However, a spokesperson for the soap told The Daily Star that the soap has a long-running history of representing people from all over the world. Read More 
“EastEnders is a fictional drama and has a rich history of representing a diverse range of religions and beliefs.” Drinking isn't allowed in the Koran (Photo: BBC) 
It comes as the show was blasted this week for turning into "Grange Hill" . 
With a host of younger characters being introduced, including Michelle's American teenager lover and her niece Bex, fans of the soap are complaining that it's not the same anymore. 
After the latest episode started with a group of school girls pining over Preston in front of Michelle, viewers raced to social media to criticise the show for turning into "teenage" drama. 
One angry fan wrote: "Since when did EastEnders become Grange Hill?"
